Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth the Manciples tale of the Crowe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the mooste lusty bachiler
(base) In al this world and eek the beste Archer
(base) He slow Phitoun the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge agayn the sonne vpon a day
(base) And many another noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wroghte as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he koude on euery Mynstralcye
(base) And syngen that it was a melodye
(base) To heren of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kyng of Thebes Amphioun
(base) That with his syngyng walled that Citee
(base) Koude neuere syngen half so wel as he
(base) Ther to he was the semelieste man
(base) That is or was sith that the world bigan
(base) What nedeth it hise fetures to discryue
(base) For in this world was noon so fair on lyue
(base) He was therwith fulfild of gentillesse
(base) Of honour and of parfit worthynesse
(base) This Phebus that was flour of Bachelrye
(base) As wel in fredom as in Chiualrye
(base) For his desport in signe eek of victorie
(base) Of Phitoun so as telleth vs the storie
(base) Was wont to beren in his hand a bowe
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a Crowe
(base) Which in a Cage he fostred many a day
(base) And taughte it speke as men teche a Iay
(base) Whit was this Crowe as is a Snow whit swan
(base) And contrefete the speche of euery man
(base) He kowde whan he sholde telle a tale
(base) Ther with in al this world no nyghtyngale
(base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Syngen so wonder myrily and weel
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
(base) Which that he louede moore than his lyf
(base) And nyght and day dide euere his diligence
(base) Hire for to plese and doon hire reuerence
(base) Saue oonly that the sothe if I shal sayn
(base) Ialous he was and wolde han kept hire fayn
(base) For hym were looth byiaped for to be
(base) And so is euery wight in swich degree
(base) But al for naught for it auaileth noght
(base) Sholde nat be kept in noon awayt certayn
(base) And trewely the labour is in vayn
(base) To kepe a shrewe .for it wol nat be
(base) This holde I for a verray nycetee
(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues
(base) Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyues
(base) But now to purpos as I first bigan
(base) This worthy Phebus dooth al that he kan
(base) To plesen hire wenynge for swich plesaunce
(base) And for his manhode and his gouernaunce
(base) That no man sholde han put hym from hire grace
(base) But god it woot ther may no man embrace
(base) As to destreyne a thyng which that nature
(base) Hath naturelly set in a creature
(base) Take any bryd and put it in a Cage
(base) And do al thyn entente and thy corage
(base) To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke
(base) Of alle deyntees that thow kanst bithynke
(base) And kepe it also clenly as thow may
(base) Although his Cage of gold be neuer so gay
(base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold
(base) Leuere in a Forest that is rude and cold
(base) Gon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse
(base) For euere this bryd wol doon his bisynesse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To eschape out of his Cage if he may
(base) His libertee this bryd desireth ay
(base) Lat take a Cat and fostre hym wel with Milk
(base) And tendre flessh and make his couche of silk
(base) And lat hym seen a Mous go by the wal
(base) Anon he weyueth Milk and flessh and al
(base) And euery deyntee that is in that hous
(base) Swich appetit hath he to ete a Mous
(base) Lo heere hath lust his domynacioun
(base) And appetit flemeth discrecioun
(base) A she wolf hath also a vileyns kynde
(base) The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde
(base) And leest of reputacioun that wol she take
(base) In tyme whan hire lust to han a make
(base) Alle thise ensamples speke I by thise men
(base) That ben vntrewe but no thyng by wommen
(base) For men han euere a likerous appetit
(base) On lower thyng to parformen hir delit
(base) Than on hire wyues be they neuer so faire
(base) Ne neuer so trewe ne so debonaire
(base) Flessh is so newfangel with meschaunce
(base) That we ne konne in no thyng han plesaunce
(base) That sowneth in to vertu any while
(base) This Phebus which that thoughte vpon no gile
(base) Deceyued was for al his iolitee
(base) For vnder hym another hadde she
(base) A man of litel reputacioun
(base) Nat worth to Phebus in comparisoun
(base) The moore harm is it happeth ofte so
(base) Of which ther cometh muchel harm and wo
(base) And so bifel whan Phebus was absent
(base) His wyf anon hath for hire lemman sent
(base) Hir lemman certes this is a knauyssh speche
(base) Foryeueth it me and that I yow biseche
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The wise Plato seith as ye may rede
(base) The word moot nede acorde with the dede
(base) If men shal telle proprely a thyng
(base) The word moot cosyn be to the werkyng
(base) I am a boystous man right thus seye I
(base) Ther nys no difference trewely
(base) Bitwix a wyf that is of heigh degree
(base) If of hire body deshoneste she be
(base) And a poore wenche oother than this
(base) If it so be they werke bothe amys
(base) But that the gentile in estat aboue
(base) She shal be clepid his lady as in loue
(base) And god it woot myn owene deere brother
(base) Men leyn that oon as lowe as lyth that oother
(base) Right so bitwix a titlelees tiraunt
(base) And an Outlawe or a theef erraunt
(base) The same I seye ther is no difference
(base) To Alisandre was told this sentence
(base) That for the tiraunt is of gretter myght
(base) By force of meyne for to sleen doun right
(base) And brennen hous and hoom and make al playn
(base) Lo therfore is he clepid a Capitayn
(base) And for the Outlawe hath but smal meynee
(base) And may nat doon so gret an harm as he
(base) Ne brynge a contree to so gret meschief
(base) Men clepen hym an Outlawe or a theef
(base) But for I am a man noght textuel
(base) I wol noght telle of textes neuer a del
(base) I wol go to my tale as I bigan
(base) Whan Phebus wyf hadde sent for hire lemman
(base) Anon they wroghte al hire lust volage
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This Crowe sang Cokkow Cokkow Cokkow
(base) What bryd quod Phebus what song syngestow
(base) Ne were thow wont so myrily to synge
(base) That to myn herte it was a reioysynge
(base) To here thy voys allas what song is this
(base) By God quod he I synge nat amys
(base) Phebus quod he for al thy worthynesse
(base) For al thy beautee and thy gentillesse
(base) For al thy song and al thy Mynstralcye
(base) For al thy waityng blered is thyn eye
(base) With oon of litel reputacioun
(base) Nat worth to thee in comparisoun
(base) The montaunce of a gnat so mote I thryue
(base) For in thy bed thy wif I sey hym et cetera
(base) What wol ye moore the Crowe anon hym tolde
(base) By sadde toknes and by wordes bolde
(base) How that his wyf hadde doon hire lecherye
(base) Hym to gret shame and to gret vileynye
(base) And tolde hym ofte he say it with hise eyen
(base) This Phebus gan aweyward for to wryen
(base) And thoughte his sorweful herte brast atwo
(base) His bowe he bente and sette ther Inne a flo
(base) And in his Ire his wyf thanne hath he slayn
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to sayn
(base) For sorwe of which he brak his Mynstralcye
(base) Bothe harpe and Lute and Gyterne and Sawtrye
(base) And eek he brak hise arwes and his bowe
(base) And after that thus spak he to the Crowe
(base) Traytour quod he with tonge of Scorpioun
(base) Thow hast me broght to my confusioun
(base) Allas that I was wroght why nere I ded
(base) O deere wyf o gemme of lustihed
(base) That were to me so sad and eek so trewe
(base) Now lystow ded with face pale of hewe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ful giltlees that dorste I swere ywys
(base) O rakel hand to doon so foule amys
(base) O trouble wit o Ire recchelees
(base) That vnauysed smytest giltlees
(base) O wantrust ful of fals suspecioun
(base) Where was thy wit and thy discrecioun
(base) O euery man be war of rakelnesse
(base) Ne trowe ye no thyng withouten strong witnesse
(base) Smyt nat to soone er that ye witen why
(base) And beth auysed wel and sobrely
(base) Er ye do any execucioun
(base) Vpon youre Ire for suspecioun
(base) Allas a thousand folk hath rakel Ire
(base) Fully fordoon or broght hem in the Myre
(base) Allas for sorwe I wol my seluen sle
(base) And to the Crowe o false theef seyde he
(base) I wol thee quyte anon thy false tale
(base) Thow songe whilom lyk a nyghtyngale
(base) Now shaltow false theef thy song forgon
(base) And eek thy white fetheres euerichon
(base) Ne neuere in al thy lyf ne shaltow speke
(base) Thus shal men on a traytour ben awreke
(base) Thow and thyn ofspryng euere shul be blake
(base) Ne neuere swete noyse shul ye make
(base) But euere crye agayn tempest and rayn
(base) In tokenynge that thurgh thee my wyf is slayn
(base) And to the Crowe he stirte and that anon
(base) And pulled hise white fetheres euerichon
(base) And made hym blak and refte hym al his song
(base) And eek his speche and out at dore hym slong
(base) Vnto the deuel which I hym bitake
(base) And for this cas ben alle Crowes blake
(base) Lordynges by this ensample I yow preye
(base) Beth war and taketh kepe what I seye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne telleth neuere no man in youre lyf
(base) How that another man hath dight his wyf
(base) He wol yow haten mortally certeyn
(base) Daun Salomon as wise clerkes seyn
(base) Techeth a man to kepen his tonge wel
(base) But as I seyde I nam nat textuel
(base) But nathelees thus taughte me my dame
(base) My sone thenk on the Crowe agoddes name
(base) A wikke tonge is worse than a feend
(base) My sone keep wel thy tonge and kepe thy freend
(base) My sone from a feend men may hem blesse
(base) My sone god of his endelees goodnesse
(base) Walled a tonge with teeth and lippes eke
(base) For man sholde hym auyse what he speeke
(base) My sone ful ofte for to muche speche
(base) Hath many a man ben spilt as clerkes teche
(base) But for litel speche auysely
(base) Is no man shent to speke generally
(base) My sone thy tonge sholdestow restreyne
(base) At alle tymes but whan thow doost thy peyne
(base) To speke of god in honour and prayere
(base) The firste vertu sone if thow wolt leere
(base) Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tonge
(base) Thus lernen children whan that they ben yonge
(base) My sone of muchel spekyng yuele auysed
(base) Ther lasse spekyng hadde ynow suffised
(base) Comth muchel harm thus was me told and taught
(base) In muchel speche synne wanteth naught
(base) Wostow wher of a rakel tonge serueth
(base) Right as a swerd forkitteth and forkerueth
(base) An arm atwo my deere sone right so
(base) A tonge kitteth frendship al atwo
(base) A Ianglere is to god abhomynable
(base) Rede Salomon so wys and honurable
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Rede Dauid in his psalmes rede Senekke
(base) My sone spek noght but with thyn hed thow bekke
(base) Dissimule as thow were deef if that thow heere
(base) A Ianglere speke of perilous matere
(base) The flemyng seith and lerne it if thee leste
(base) That litel Ianglyng causeth muchel reste
(base) My sone if thow no wikked word hast seyd
(base) Thee thar nat drede for to be biwreyd
(base) But he that hath mysseyd I dar wel sayn
(base) He may by no wey clepe his word agayn
(base) Thyng that is sayd is seyd and forth it gooth
(base) Though hym repente or be hym leef or looth
(base) He is his thral to whom that he hath sayd
(base) A tale of which he is now yuele apayd
(base) My sone be war and be noon Auctour newe
(base) Of tidynges wher they ben false or trewe
(base) Wher so thow come amonges heye or lowe
(base) Kepe wel thy tonge and thynk vpon the Crowe
(base) Here is ended the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Thopas
(base) LIsteth lordes in good entent
(base) And I wil telle verrayment
(base) Of myrthe and of solas
(base) Al of a knyght was fair and gent
(base) In bataille and in tornament
(base) His name was sir Thopas
(base) Yborn he was in fer contree
(base) In Flaundres al biyonde the see
(base) At Poperyng in the place
(base) His fader was a man ful free
(base) And lord he was of that contree
(base) As it was goddes grace

div.l: (base) Sire Thopas wax a doghty swayn
(base) Whit was his face as Payndemayn
(base) His lippes reed as Rose
(base) His rode is lyk Scarlet in grayn
(base) As I yow telle in good certayn
(base) He hadde a semely nose
(base) His heer his berd was lyk Safrown
(base) That to his girdel raughte adown
(base) His shoon of Cordewane
(base) Of Brugges were his hosen brown
(base) His Robe was of Syklatown
(base) That coste many a Iane
(base) He koude hunte at wilde deer
(base) And ride an hawkyng for Ryuer
(base) With grey goshauk on honde
(base) Ther to he was a good Archier
(base) Of wrastlyng was ther noon his pier
(base) Ther any Ram shal stonde
(base) Ful many mayde bright in bour
(base) They moorne for hym paramour
(base) Whan hem were bet to slepe
(base) But he was chaast and no lechour
(base) And swete as is the brambel flour
(base) That bereth the rede hepe
(base) That bereth þᵉ reed hepe
(base) And so it fel vpon a day
(base) For sothe as I yow telle may
(base) Sire Thopas wolde out ryde
(base) He warth vpon his Steede gray
(base) And in his hand a launcegay
(base) A long Swerd by his syde
(base) He priketh thurgh a fair Forest
(base) Ther Inne is many a wilde best
(base) Ye bothe bukke and hare
(base) And as he priketh North and Est
(base) I telle it yow hym hadde almest
(base) Bitydde a sory care
(base) There spryngen herbes grene and smale
(base) The Licorys and Cetewale
(base) And many a clowe Gylofre
(base) And notemuge to putte in Ale
(base) Wheither it be moyste or stale
(base) Or for to leye in cofre
(base) The bryddes synge it is no nay
(base) The Sparhauk and the Popyniay
(base) That ioye it was to here
(base) The thurstelcok made eek his lay
(base) The wodedowue vpon the spray
(base) She sang ful loude and clere
(base) Sire Thopas fil in loue longynge

(base) And pryked as he were wood

div.l: (base) His fayre Steede in his prikynge
(base) So swatte that men myghte hym wrynge
(base) Hys sydes were al blood
(base) Sire Thopas eek so wery was
(base) For prikyng on the softe gras
(base) So fiers was his corage
(base) That doun he leyde hym in the plas
(base) To make his Steede som solas
(base) And yaf hym good forage

(base) O Seinte Marie benedicite
(base) What eyleth this loue at me
(base) To bynde me so soore
(base) Me dremed al this nyght pardee
(base) An Elf queene shal my lemman be

(base) For in this world no womman is

(base) in towne
(base) Alle othere wommen I forsake
(base) And to an Elf queene I me take

(base) An Elf queene for tespye

(base) That he had of ony drede
(base) foundyn in no stede .

(base) A perilous man of dede

(base) But if thow pryke out of myn haunt
(base) Anon I sle thy Steede
(base) With Mace
(base) Heere is this queene of Fairye
(base) With harpe and pipe and Symphonye
(base) Dwellyng in this place
(base) The child seyde als mote I thee
(base) Tomorwe wol I meete thee

(base) That thow shalt with this launcegay

(base) Shal I percen if I may
(base) Er it be fully pryme of day
(base) For here shaltow ben slawe
(base) Sire Thopas drow abak ful faste
(base) This geant at hym stones caste

div.l: (base) And al it was thurgh goddes graas

(base) 3et lesteth lordes to my tale
(base) Murier than the nyghtyngale
(base) I wol yow rowne

(base) Prikyng ouer hyll and dale

div.l: (base) That bodeth werre and no thyng pes
(base) The heed ful sharp ygrounde
(base) His Steede was al dappel gray
(base) It goth an Ambel in the way
(base) Ful softely and rounde
(base) In londe
(base) Lo lordes myne here is a fit
(base) If ye wole any moore of it
(base) To telle it wol I fonde
(base) NOw hoold youre mouth par charitee
(base) Bothe knyght and lady free
(base) And herkneth to my spell
(base) Of bataille and of chiualry
(base) And of ladyes loue drury
(base) Anon I wol yow tell
(base) Men speken of Romances of pris
(base) Of Hornchild and of Ypotys
(base) Of Beves and Sir Gy
(base) Of Sire lybeux and playn damour
(base) But sire Thopas he bereth the flour
(base) Of real Chiualry
(base) His goode Steede al he bystrood
(base) And forth vpon his wey he glood
(base) As Sparcle out of the bronde
(base) Vpon his Creest he bar a tour
(base) And ther Inne stiked a lilie flour
(base) God shilde his cors fro shonde
(base) And for he was a knyght auntrous
(base) He nolde slepen in noon hous
(base) But liggen in his hode
(base) His brighte helm was his wonger
(base) And by hym bayteth his destrer
(base) Of herbes fyne and goode
(base) Hymself drank water of the well
(base) As dide the knyght Sire Percyuell
(base) So worly vnder wede
(base) Til on a day
(base)

(base) ¶ Here the hoost stynteth Chaucer of his tale of
Thopas / and biddeth hym / telle another tale
(base) Namoore of this / for goddes dignytee
(base) Quod oure hoost for thow makest me
(base) For thou so werry makist me
(base) So wery / of thy verray lewednesse
(base) Of thy verry lewdnesse
(base) That also wisly / god my soule blesse
(base) Myne erys aken / of thy drasty speche
(base) Now swich a rym / the deuel I biteche
(base) This may wel be / rym dogerel quod he
(base) ¶ Why so quod I / why wol thow lette me
(base) Moore of my tale / than another man
(base) Syn that it is / the beste rym I kan
(base) ¶ By god quod he / for pleynly at o word
(base) Thy drasty rymyng is nat worth a tord
(base) Thow doost noght ellis / but despendest tyme
(base) Sire at o word / thow shalt no lenger ryme
(base) Lat se / wher thow kanst tellen aught in geste
(base) Or tel in prose / som what at the leeste

div.l: (base) In which ther be som myrthe / or som doctrine
(base) ¶ Gladly quod I / by goddes swete pyne
(base) I wol yow telle / a litel thyng in prose
(base) That oghte like yow / as I suppose
(base) Or ellis certes / ye be to daungerous
(base) It is a moral tale vertuous
(base) Al be it toold som tyme in sondry wise
(base) Of sondry folk / as I shal yow deuyse
(base) ¶ As thus / ye woot that euery Euangelist
(base) That telleth vs / the peyne of Ihu Crist
(base) Ne seith nat alle thyng as his felawe dooth
(base) But nathelees / hir sentence is al sooth
(base) And alle acorden / as in hir sentence
(base) Al be ther / in hir tellyng difference
(base) For somme of hem seyn moore / and somme seyn lesse
(base) Whan they / his pitous passion expresse
(base) I mene / of Mark / Mathew / Luk and Iohn
(base) But doutelees / hir sentence is al oon
(base) ¶ Therfore / lordynges alle / I yow biseche
(base) If that ye thynke / I varie / as in my speche
(base) As thus / thogh that I telle somwhat moore
(base) Of prouerbes / than ye han herd bifore
(base) Comprehended / in this litel tretys heere
(base) To enforcen with / theffect of my matere
(base) And thogh I nat the same wordes seye
(base) As ye han herd / yet to yow alle I preye
(base) Blameth me nat / for as in my sentence
(base) Shul ye / nowher / fynden difference
(base) Fro the sentence / of this tretys lite
(base) After the which / this myry tale I write
(base) And therfore herkneth / what that I shal seye
(base) And lat me tellen / al my tale I preye
(base) Here endith Chaucers tale of sir Thopas
(base) A . doughty knyght in alle his dede
(base) God help us alle and seint Thomas
(base) And graunt us his grace wele to spede . Amen
(base) Here endeth Chauncers tale of Thopas
(base) ¶ Explicit ~
(base) Sequitur Chawcers tale .

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Prudence suffred hir housbonde for to
wepe and crye as for a certeyn space

(base) and whan she say hir
tyme she seyde hym in this wise Allas my lord quod she
why make ye your self for to be lyk a fool
(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre
doghter with the grace of god shal warisshe and escape

(base) And al were it so that she right now were deed ye ne oghte nat as
for hir deth youre self to destroye

(base) Senec seith the wise man
shal nat take to greet disconfort for the deth of his children

(base) but
certes he sholde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the
deth of his owene propre perrsone

(base) This Melibeus answerde anon
and seyde What man quod he sholde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so gret a cause for to wepe

(base) Ihus crist oure lord hym
self wepte for the deth of lazarus his freend

(base) Prudence
answerde Certes wel I woot attempree wepynge is no thyng
defended to hym that sorweful is amonges folk in sorwe but
it is rather graunted hym to wepe

(base) The Apostle Poul vn to
the Romayns writeth Man shal reioysse with hem that maken ioye
and wepen with swich folk as wepen

(base) but thogh attempree
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
wepyng be graunted outrageous wepyng certes is defended

(base) Mesure
of wepyng sholde be considered after the loore that techeth vs
Senec

(base) Whan that thy freend is deed quod he lat nat thyne eyen
to moyste ben of terys ne to muche drye al thogh the teerys
come to thyne eyen lat hem nat falle

(base) And whan thou hast
forgoon thy freend do diligence to geten another freend and
this is moore wysdom than for to wepe for thy freend which
that thou hast lorn for ther Inne is no boote

(base) And therfore if ye
gouerne yow by Sapience put awey sorwe out of youre herte

(base) Remembre yow that Ihus Syrak seith A man that is ioyous and
glad in herte it hym conserueth florisshynge in his age but
soothly sorweful herte maketh his bones drye

(base) he seith eek
thus that sorwe in herte sleeth ful many a man

(base) Salomon
seith that right as Moththes in the Shepes flees anoyeth
to the clothes and the smale wormes to the tree right so anoyeth sorwe to the herte

(base) wher fore vs oghte as wel in the deth
of oure children as in the losse of oure goodes temporels haue
pacience

(base) Remembre yow vp on the pacient Iob whan he
hadde lost his children and his temporel substance and in his body
endured and receyued ful many a greuous tribulacion yet seide
he thus
(base) Oure lord quod he hath yeue it me

(base) Oure lord hath biraft it me right so as oure lord
hath wold right so it is doon yblessed be the name of oure
lord

(base) To thise forseyde thynges answerde Melibeus vn to
his wif Prudence Alle thy wordes quod he been sothe and
ther to profitable but trewely myn herte is troubled with this
sorwe so greuously that I noot what to doon

(base) lat calle quod
Prudence thy trewe freendes alle and thy lynage whiche that
ben wise telleth youre cas and herkneth what they seye in conseylynge
and yow gouerne after hir sentence

(base) Salomon seith werk
alle thy thynges by conseil and thow shalt neuere repente

(base) Thanne by the conseil of his wyf Prudence this Melibeus leet
callen a greet congregacioun of folk

(base) as Sirurgiens Phisiciens
olde folk and yonge and somme of hise olde enemys reconsiled as
by hir semblant to his loue and in to his grace

(base) and ther with al ther
coomen somme of hise neghebores that diden hym reuerence moore
for drede than for loue as it happeth ofte

(base) Ther coomen also
ful manye subtile flaterers and wise Aduocatz lerned in the
lawe

(base) And
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
whan this folk togydre assembled weren this Melibeus in sorweful wise shewed hem his cas

(base) and by the manere
of his speche it semed that in herte he baar a cruel Ire redy to
doon vengeance vp on his foos and sodeynly desired that the
werre sholde bigynne

(base) but nathelees yet axed he hir conseil
vp on this matere

(base) A Sirurgien by licence and assent of swiche
as were wise vp roos and vn to Melibeus seyde as ye may
heere

(base) Sire quod he as to vs Sirurgiens aperteneth that we
do to euery wight the beste that we kan where as we be withholden
and to oure pacientz that we do no damage

(base) wher fore it
happeth many tyme and ofte that whan twey men han euerich
wounded oother o same Sirurgien heeleth hem bothe

(base) wher
fore vn to oure Art it is nat pertinent to norice werre ne parties
to supporte

(base) but certes as to the warisshynge of youre doghter
al be it so that she perilously be wounded we shullen do so ententif bisynesse fro day to nyght that with the grace of god she
shal be hool and sound as soone as is possible

(base) Almoost right
in the same wise the Phisiciens answerden saue that they
seyden a fewe wordes moore

(base) that right as maladyes
ben cured by hir contraries right so shal man warisshe
werre by vengeance

(base) hise neghebores ful of enuye hise
feyned freendes that semeden reconsiled hise flaterers

(base) maden
semblant of wepyng and empeyred and agregged muchel
of this matere in preisynge gretly Melibe of myght of
power of richesse and of freendes despisynge the power
of hise Aduersaries

(base) and seyden outrely that he anon sholde
wreke hym on hise foos and bigynne werre

(base) Vp roos thanne an Aduocat that was wys by leue and by conseil of othere
that weren wise and seyde

(base) Lordynges the nede for the which
we ben assembled in this place is ful heuy thyng and an
heigh matere

(base) by cause of the wrong and of the wikkednesse that
hath be doon and eek by reson of the grete damages that in tyme
comynge been possible to fallen for the same cause

(base) And ek
by reson of the grete richesse and power of the parties bothe

(base) for
the whiche resons it were a ful greet peril to erren in this matere

(base) Wher fore Melibeus this is oure sentence we conseile
yow abouen alle thyng that right anon thow do diligence in
kepynge of thy propre persone in swich a wise
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
that thow ne wante noon espye ne wacche thy body for to saue

(base) And after that
we conseille that in thyn hous thow sette suffisant garnyson so that they may as wel thy body as thyn hous defende

(base) But certes for to moeue werre ne sodeynly for to doon
vengeance we may nat deme in so litel tyme that it were
profitable
(base) wher fore we axen leyser and espace to haue deliberacioun in this cas to deme

(base) for the commune prouerbe seyth
this he that soone demeth soone shal repente

(base) And eek men
seyn that thilke Iuge is wys that soone vnderstondeth a matere and Iuggeth by leyser

(base) for al be it so that al taryyng be
anoyful algates it is nat to repreue in yeuyng of Iuggement ne in vengeance takyng whan it is suffisant and
resonable

(base) and that shewed oure lord Ihus crist by ensample for whan that the womman that was taken in auoutrye
was broght in his presence to knowen what sholde be doon
with hir persone al be it that he wiste wel hym self what
that he wolde answere yet ne wolde he nat answere sodeynly but he wolde haue deliberacioun and in the ground he
wroot twies

(base) and bythise causes we axen deliberacion
and we shul thanne by the grace of god conseille thee thyng
that shal be profitable

(base) Vp stirten thanne the yonge folk
atones and the mooste partie of that compaignye han scorned this olde wise man and bigonnen to make noyse and
seyden that

(base) right so as whil that Iren is hoot men sholde smyte right so sholde men wreken hir wronges
whil that they been fresshe and newe and with loud voys
they criden werre werre

(base) vp roos tho oon of thise olde
wise and with his hand made contenance that men sholde
holden hem stille and yeuen hym audience

(base) Lordynges quod he ther is ful many a man that crieth werre
werre that woot ful litel what werre amounteth

(base) Werre at his bigynnyng hath so greet an entree and so large
that euery wight may entre whan hym liketh and lightly fynde werre

(base) But certes what ende that ther of shal falle it
is noght light to knowe

(base) for soothly whan that werre is ones
bigonne ther is ful many a child vnborn of his moder
that shal sterue yong by cause of thilke werre or ellis lyue in
sorwe and dye in wrecchednesse

(base) and ther fore er that any werre
be bigonne men
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
moste haue gret conseil and gret deliberacioun

(base) And whan this olde man wende to enforcen his tale by resons
wel neigh all atones bigonne they to rise for to breken his tale and beden hym ful ofte hise wordes for to abregge

(base) for sothly he that precheth to hem that listen nat heren hise wordes hys
sarmon hem anoyeth

(base) For Ihus Syrak seith That Musyk in
wepynge is a noyous thyng This is to seyn As muche auaileth to speken biforn folk to whiche his speche anoyeth as it
is to synge biforn hym that wepeth

(base) And whan this wise man
say that hym wanted audience al shamefast he sette hym doun
agayn

(base) For Salomon seith ther as thow ne mayst haue non
audience enforce thee nat to speke

(base) I se wel quod this wise
man that the come prouerbe is sooth that good conseil wanteth
whan it is moost nede

(base) yet hadde this Melibeus in his conseil many folk that priuely in his ere conseiled hym certeyn
thyng and conseiled hym the contrarie in general audience

(base) Whan Melibeus hadde herd that the gretteste party of his conseil were acorded that he sholde make werre anon he consented
to hir conseilyng and fully affermed hir sentence

(base) Thanne dame Prudence whan that she say how that hyr
housbonde shoope hym for to wreke hym on his foos and to
bigynne werre she in ful humble wise whan she say hir
tyme seyde hym thise wordes

(base) My lord quod she I you
biseche as hertely as I dar and kan ne haste yow nat to
faste and for alle gerdons as yif me audience

(base) For Piers
Alfonce seith who so that dooth to thee outher good or
harm haste thee nat to quiten it for in this wise thy
freend wol abyde and thyn enemy shal the lenger lyue
in drede

(base) The prouerbe seith he hasteth wel that wysly kan
abide and in wikked haste is no profit

(base) This Melibe answerde vn to his wyf Prudence I purpose nat quod he
to werken by thy conseil for many causes and resons
for certes euery wight wolde holde me thanne a fool

(base) this is to seyn If I for thy conseilyng wolde chaunge
thynges that ben ordeyned and affermed by so manye wise

(base) Secoundly I seye that alle wommen ben wikke and noon good of hem alle
for of a thousand men seith Salomon I foond o good man but
certes of alle wommen good womman foond
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
I neuere

(base) And also certes
if I gouerned me by thy conseil it sholde seme that I hadde yeue
to thee ouer me the maistrie and goddes forbode that it so were

(base) For Ihus Syrak seith that if the wyf haue maistrie she is
contrarious to hir housbonde

(base) And Salomon seith Neuere
in thy lyf to thy wyf ne to thy child ne to thy freend ne yif
no power ouer thy self For bettre it were that thy children
axen of thy persone thynges that hem nedeth than thow see
thy self in the handes of thy children

(base) And also if I wolde
werke by thy conseilyng certes my conseil moste som tyme be
secree til it were tyme that it moste be knowe and this ne
may nat be

(base) Whan Dame Prudence ful debonairly and with
gret pacience hadde herd al that hir housbonde liked for to
seye thanne axed she of hym licence for to speke and
seyde in this wise

(base) My lord quod she as to youre firste
reson certes it may lightly been answered for I seye that it is
no folie to chaunge conseil whan the thyng is chaunged
or ellis whan the thyng semeth oother weys than it was
biforn

(base) And moore ouer I seye that thogh that ye han sworn
and bihight to perfourne youre emprise and nathelees ye weyue
to perfourne thilke same emprise by iuste cause men sholde nat seyn therfore that ye were a lyere ne forsworn

(base) for
the book seith that the wise man maketh no lesyng whan
he turneth his corage to the bettre

(base) And al be it so that youre
emprise be establissed and ordeyned by gret multitude of folk
yet thar ye nat accomplice thilke same ordinance but yow
like

(base) for the trouthe of thynges and the profit ben rather founde
in fewe folk that ben wise and ful of reson than by gret multitude of folk ther euery man crieth and clatereth what that hym
liketh soothly swich multitude is nat honeste

(base) And to the
Seconde resoun where as ye seyn that alle wommen ben wikke
Saue youre grace certes ye despise alle wommen in this wyse
and he that al despiseth al displeseth as seith the book

(base) and
Senec seith that who so wole haue Sapience shal no man
dispreise but he shal gladly teche the science that he kan with
oute presumpcion or pride

(base) and swiche thynges as he noght
ne kan he shal nat ben ashamed to lerne hem and enquere
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
of lasse folk than hym self

(base) And sire that ther hath be ful many
a good womman may lightly be preued

(base) for certes sire oure lord
Ihus crist wolde neuere han descended to be born of a womman
if alle wommen hadde be wikke

(base) And after that for the grete
bountee that is in wommen oure lord Ihus crist whan he was risen
fro deth to lyf appered rather to a womman than to his apostles

(base) And though that Salomon seith that he ne foond neuere
womman good it folweth nat therfore that alle wommen
ben wikke

(base) for thogh that he ne foond no good womman certes
many another man hath founde many a womman ful good
and trewe

(base) Or ellis parauenture the entente of Salomon was
this that as in souereyn bountee he foond no womman

(base) this is
to seyn that ther is no wight that hath souereyn bountee saue
god allone as he hym self recordeth in his Euangelie

(base) for
ther nys no creature so good that hym ne wanteth som what
of the perfeccioun of god that is his makere

(base) Youre thridde reson is this ye seyn that if ye gouerne yow by my conseil it
sholde seme that ye hadde yeue me the maistrie and the lordshipe ouer youre persone

(base) Sire sauf youre grace it is nat so
for if so were that no man sholde be conseiled but oonly of
hem that hadde lordshipe and maistrie of his persone men wolde nat ben conseiled so ofte

(base) for soothly thilke man that axeth
conseil of a purpos yet hath he free choys wheither he
wole werke by that conseil or noon

(base) And as to youre ferthe
reson ther ye seyn that the Ianglerye of wommen kan hide
thynges that they woot nat as who seith that a womman
kan nat hide that that she woot

(base) Sire thise wordes been
vnderstonde of wommen that ben Iangleresses and wikked

(base) of
whiche wommen men seyn that thre thynges dryuen a man
out of his hous that is to seyn Smoke droppyng of
reyn and wikked wyues

(base) and of swiche wommen seith Salomon that it were bettre dwellen in desert than with a womman
that is riotous
(base) and sire by youre leue that am nat I

(base) for ye han
ful ofte assayed my grete silence and my grete pacience and
eek how wel that I kan hiden and hele thynges that men oghten
secrely to hyde

(base) And soothly as to youre fifthe reson wher-
as ye seyn that in wikked conseil wommen venquysse men
god woot thilke reson stant heere in no stede
(base) For vnderstond now ye axen conseil to do wikkednesse

(base) and if ye
wol werke wikkednesse and youre wyf restreyneth thilke
wikked purpos and ouercometh yow by reson and by good conseil

(base) certes youre
wyf oghte
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
rather be preysed than yblamed
(base) Thus sholde ye vnderstonde the Philosophre that seith In wikked conseil wommen venquyssen hir housbondes

(base) And ther as ye blamen alle wommen
and hir resons I shal shewe by manye ensamples that many a
womman hath be ful good and yet ben and hir conseils holsom
and profitable
(base) Eke som men han seyd that the conseilyng of wommen is outher to deere or ellis to litel of prys

(base) but al be it
so that ful many a womman is badde and hir conseil vile and noght
worth yet han men founde ful many a good womman and ful
discrete and wys in conseilynge

(base) Lo Iacob by conseil of his
moder Rebekka wan the beneyson of Ysaak his fader and
the lordshipe ouer alle his bretheren

(base) Iudith by hir good conseil
deliuered the Citee of Bethulye in which she dwelled out of the
handes of Olofernus that hadde it biseged and wolde it al destroye

(base) Abigail deliuered Nabal hir housbonde fro Dauid the kyng that
wolde han slayn hym and apaised the Ire of the kyng by hir
wit and by hir good conseilyng

(base) Hester by hir good conseil enhaunced gretly the peple of god in the regne of Assuerus the
kyng

(base) and the same bountee in good conseilyng of many a good
womman may men telle

(base) And moore ouer whan that oure lord
hadde creat Adam oure forme fader he seyde in this wise

(base) It is nat good to be a man allone make we to hym an help
semblable to hym self

(base) Heere may ye se that if that wommen
were nat goode and hir conseil good and profitable

(base) oure lord god

hi.hi: Here beginneth the Nonnes Prestes tale of Chauntecler ⁊and Pertelote .

l.hi: pore widewe somdel stope in age ~

div.l: Was whilom dwelling in a narwe cotage
Beside a groue dwelling in a dale
This widewe of whom I telle my tale
Synnes thilk day she was a wif
In pacience ledde a full simple lif
For litell was her catell and her rent
By husbondry of such as god her sent
She fonde her self and eke her douȝteres two
Thre large sowes had she and nomo
Three keen and eke a sheep that hiȝt malle
Ful soty was her boure and eke her halle
In which she ete many a slender mele
Of poinant sauce her nedith neuer a dele
No deynte morsell passid her throte
Her dyet was according to her cote
Replecioıı̄un made her neuer seke
Attemꝑper/par diet was all her phisik
And excercise was and hertes suffisaunce
And the goute let her neuer for to daunce
Ne poplexie shent not her hede
Ne wyne drank she non white nor rede
Her borde was most serued with white and blak
Melk and broun bred in which she fand no lak
Seynde bacoıı̄un and somtyme an ey or twey
For she was as it were a maner deye
A gardyn she had closed all a boute
With stikkes and a drye diche all a boute
In which she had a Cok that hiȝt Chaunteclere
In all the lond of crowing nas his pere
His voice was merier than the mery orgon
On masse daies that in the chirche goon
Wel sikerer was his crowing in his logge Chauntecler ~
Than is A clokke in abbey or in orelogge
By nature he croweth eche assencioıı̄un
Of equenocciall in thilke toun
For when degrees xv. were ascended
Than crew he that it miȝt not be amended
His combe was redder than the fyne corall
And batailed as it were a castell wall
His bill was blak and as the Ieet it shone
I like azure were his leggis and his toon
His nayles whitter were than the lily flour
And like bornesshid gold was his colour
This gentill cokke had in his gouernᵃnce
Seuene hennes to don him plesaunce
Which were sustres and his paramours
And wondir like to him as of coloures
Of which the fairest hewed in her cote
Was clepid faire damisell Pertelote
Curteis she was discret and debonair
And compenable and bar her self so faire
Sethines thilk day she was seueniȝt olde
That truly she hath in herte in holde
Of Chaunteclere loken in eueri sith
He loued her so that wel was him ther with
But such a ioye it was to here him singe
Whan that the briȝt sonne began to springe
In swete accord my lef is faren a londe
For thilke tyme as I haue vnderstonde
Bestes and briddes coude speke and synge
And so befell that in the dawening
As Chaunteclere amonges his wyues alle
Sat on the perche that was in the halle
And next him sat this faire Pertelote
This Chaunteclere gan grone in his throte
As a man that in his dreem drecchid sore Pertelote ~
And whan this Pertelote thus herd him rore
She was agast and seide herte dere
What eileth you to grone in that manere
Ye be a verry sleper fy for shame
And he answerid and seide thus madame
I pray you that ye take it nouȝt agreef
By god me thouȝt I was in such mischief
Riȝt now that yet myn herte is sore a fliȝt
Now god qd he my sweuene recche ariȝt
And kepe my body out of foule prisoıı̄un
Me mette that I romed vp and doun
Withinne oure yerd where as I sauȝ a beest
Was like an hounde and wolde haue made arest
Vpon my body and wolde haue had me deed
His colour was bitwen white and reed
And tipped was his tayle and vp stood his eres
With blak on like the remenᵃnt of his heres
His snoute smal with glowing eyen twey
Yet for his loke almost I dey
This caused me my groning douteles
A voy qd she fy on you herteles
Allas qd she for by that god aboue
Now haue ye lost myn hert and my loue
I can not loue a coward be my feith
For certes what so eny womman seith
We alle desiren if it may be
To haue husbondes wise hardy and free
And secree ne no nigard ne fole
Ne him that is agast of eueri tooll
Ne non auauntour by that god aboue
Hou dorst ye say for shame to your loue
That any thing miȝt make you aferd
Haue ye no manes hert and a berde
Allas and can ye ben agast of sweuenes Chauntecler ~
No thing god wot but vanite in sweuene is
And ofte of fume and of complexions
Sweuenes engendren of replexions
Whan humors ben to habundant in a wiȝt
Certes this dreem which ye haue met to niȝt
Cometh of gret superfluite
Of your gret colerik parde
Which causeth folk to dreden in her dremes
Of arwes and of fire with rede lemes
Of red bestes that thei wolde hem bite
Of contek and of whelpes gret and lite
Riȝt as the humoᵘur of malencoly
Causeth many man in his sleep crye
For fere of beres or of boles blake
Orellis blake deuelis woll him take
Of othir humors coude I telle also
That worken many a man in his slepe full woo
But I will passe as liȝtly as I can
Loo Catoıı̄un which is so wise a man
Seide he nat thus ne do ye no force of dremes
Now sir qd she whan we flie fro this bemes
For goddis loue as takith som laxatyue
Vpon perill of my soule and of myne lyue
I counseill you the best I will nat lie
Ye beth of colerik and of malencolie
Ye purge you for ye ne shall nat tarie
Thouȝ in this toun is non appotecary
I shall my self to herbes telle you
That shall be for your hele and your prow
And in the gardyn the herbes shall ye fynde
The which haue of here propirtees the kynde
To purge you beneth and eke aboue
Foryete nouȝt this for goddes owne loue
Ye bene full colerik of complexioıı̄un Pertelot ~
Whan the sonne is in his assencioıı̄un
Ne fynde you replete of humoᵘurs hote
And yef he do I dar wel ley a grote
That ye shall haue a feuer tercian
Or an hagu that may be your ban
A day or ij ye shall haue digestyues
Of wormes or ye take your laxatyues
Of laurel centaure and fumytere
Orellis of elbere that groweth there
Of quaterpuce or of gaytres beryes
Of herbe Iue growing in your gardyn there mery is
Pekke hem riȝt vp as thei growe and ete hem yn
Be mery husbond for your fader kyn
Dredith no dreme I can sey you nomore
Madame qd he graunt mercy for your lore
But natheles as touching Dam Catoıı̄un
That hath of wisdom such a gret renoıı̄un
By god men may in olde bokes rede
Thouȝ that he bad no dremes for to drede
Of many man more of Auctoritee
Than euer Catoıı̄un was so mote I the
That alle the reuerse seyn of his sentence
And han wel founden by experience
That dremes ben significacions
As well of ioye as of tribulacions
That folk enduren in this lif present
Ther nedith to make of this argument
The verry preef shewith it in dede
One of the grettest Auctoᵘur that men rede
Saith thus that ij felawes went
On pilgrimage in a full gode entent
And happid so they cam in to a toun
Where as there was such a congregacioıı̄un
Of people / and eke of streyte herbigage Chauntecler ~
That they founde not as moch as a cotage
In which thei miȝt bothe I loggid be
Wherfor thei most of necessite
As for that niȝt departen companye
And eche of hem goth to his hostelrie
And toke his logge as it wolde falle
That oon of hem was logged in a stalle
Fer in the yerd with oxen of the plouȝ
That other man was logged wel Inouȝ
As was his aduenture or his fortune
That vs all gouerneth as in comune
And so it be fell long or it was day
This man mette in his bedde there he lay
How that his felaw gan vpon him calle
And he seide allas for in an oxes stalle
This niȝt I shall be murdered as I lie
Now helpe me dere brothir or I dye
In alle hast come to me he saide
This man oute of his sleep for fere he braide
But whan that he was wakid out of his sleep
He torned him and toke of this no kepe
Him thouȝt his dreem nas but a vanite
Thus twies in his sleping dremed he
And at the thridde tyme yet his felawe
Cam as him thouȝt I am nowe slawe
Byholde my body wounded dep and wide
Arise vp erly in the morn tyde
And at the west gate of the toun qd he
A cart full of donge ther shalt thou see
In which my body is hid full preuily
Do thilke cart arest boldely
My gold caused my deth soth to sayn
And tolde eueri point how he was slayn
With a full pitous face pale of hewe Pertelot ~
And trust wel this dreem he fond full trewe
For on the morn as sone as it was day
To his felawes Inne he toke the way
And whan that he come to this oxe stalle
Aftir his felaw he began to calle
The hosteler answerid him anoon
And saide sir your felawe is goon
As sone as day he went out of toun
This man gan anon falle in suspeccioıı̄un
Remembring of his dreem that he mette
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto the west gate of the toun he fonde
A donge cart went as it were to donge londe
That was arraied in the same wise
As ye herd the dede man deuise
And with an hardy hert he gan to crye
Vengeaunce and iustice of this felonye
My felaw murdred is this same niȝt
And in this cart he lieth gaping vp riȝt
I crie vpon the ministres qd he
That schuld rule and kepe this citee
Harrow allas here lieth my felaw slayn
What shall I more vnto this sayn
The people vp sterte and cast the cart to the ground
And in the middel of the donge thei founde
This dede man that murdred was all newe
O blisfull god that art iuste and true
Loo hou thou bewreiest murdre all wey
Murdre will out that se we day be day
Murdre is al waltsom and alabhominable
To god that is so iuste and resonable
That he wil nouȝt suffred it heled be
Thouȝ it a bide a yere or ij or three
Murdre wil out that is my conclusioıı̄un Chauntecler ~
And riȝt anon ministres of the toun
Haue hent the carter and sore him pyned
And eke the hostiler so sore engyned
That thei beknewe her wickidnesse anon
And were hanged by the necke bon
Here may men see that dremes ben to drede
And certes in the same book I rede
Riȝt in the next Chapitre aftir this
I gabbe not so haue I ioye or blisse
Two men that wold haue passid ouer the see
For certein cause in to a ferre contre
If that the wynd ne had ben contrarye
That made hem in a citee for to tarie
That stood full mery vpon an hauen side
But oo day ayenst the euen tide
The wynde gan chaᵘnge and blowe as hem lest
Ioly and glad thei wenten vnto rest
And casten hem full erly for to seile
But herken hou that a man fille in gret pereill
That oon of hem in sleping as he lay
Him mette a wondre dreem agein the day
Him thouȝt a man stode be his beddis side
And him cōmmaunded that he shuld a bide
And saide him thus if thou to morwe wende
Thou shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He woke and tolde his felawes what he mette
And praied hem his viage for to lette
As for that day he preid for to a bide
His felaw that lay by his beddis side
Gan for to laugh and scorned him full faste
No dreem qd he makith so myn hert agast
That I will lette for to do my thinges
I set nouȝt a straw be thi dremynges
For sweuenes ben but vanitees and iapes Pertelote ~
Men dreme all day of oules and apes
And of many a mase ther with all
Men dreme of thinges that neuer was ne neuer shall
But sith I see that thou wilt here abide
And thus forsleuthen welfully thi tide
God wot it reweth me and haue good day
And thus he toke his leue and went his way
But or that he had half his cours I seiled
Note I not whi ne what mischaunce it eiled
But casuelly the shippes botme rent
And ship and man vnder the water went
In siȝt of othir shippes him beside
That with him sailed at the same tide
And therfor faire Pertelote so dere
By such ensamples olde maist thou lere
That noman shuld be to recheles
Of dremes for I say douteles
That many a dreme full sore is for to drede
Loo in the lif of seint kenelme I rede
That was kenelphus sone the noble king
Of mercurik hou kenelme mette a thing
A litel or he was murdred on a day
His murdre in his a visioıı̄un he say
His norice him expouned eueridell
His sweuene / and for to kepen him well
Fro tresoıı̄un but he was but vij yere olde
And therfor litill tale hath he tolde
Of eny dreme so holi was his herte
By god I had leuer than my sherte
That ye had red his legende as haue I
Dame Pertelote I sey you truly
Macrobeus that writeth the a visioıı̄un
In Affryk with the worthi Ciprioıı̄un
Affermeth dremes and seith that thei ben Chauntecler ~
Warnyng of thinges that men aftir seen
And furthermore I pray you loke well
The olde testament of Daniell
Yef ye holde dremes any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and othir shul ye see
Whethir dremes ben som tyme I sey nat all
Warnyng of thinges that shall aftir fall
Loke of Egipte the king Daun Pharaoo
His boteler and his baker also
Whethir thei ne felte non effect in dremes
Who so will seke Octy of sondry realmes
May rede of dremes many a wondir thing
Loo Cresus which that was of lide king
Mette he nat that he sat vpon a tree
Which signified that he shuld hanged be
Loo here Andromacha Ectores wif
That day that Ector shulde lese his lif
She dremed on the same niȝt beforn
Hou that the lif of Ector shulde be lorn
Yef thilke day he were hent in bataile
She warned him but it miȝt not auaile
He went for to fiȝt natheles
But he was slayn of oon Achilles
But thilke tale is longe to telle
And it is nere day I may no lenger dwelle
Truli I say as for conclusion
That I shall haue of this a vision
Aduersitees and I further sey more
That I ne telle of laxatiue no store
For thei ben venymous I wot it well
I hem defie I loue hem neuer a dele
Now let us speke of mirthe and leue all this
Madame Pertelote so haue I blisse
Of oo thing god sent me hath large grace Pertelote ~
For when I see your beaute of your face
Ye ben so scarlet rede abouten your yen
Hit makith all my drede for to dyen
For as siker as is in principio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame this sentence of this latyn is
Wommām his manes ioye and his blisse
For whan I fele a niȝt youre soft side
Al be it that I may not on you ride
For that your perche is maked narwe allas
I am so full of ioye and solace
That I defie bothe sweuene and dreem
And with that word he fley doun from the beme
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a clokkyng he gan hem calle
For he had found a corne lye in the yerde
Riall he was and namore a ferde
He fethered Pertelote . xxty tyme
And trade as ofte or it were pryme
He loketh as it were a grym lyoıı̄un
And on his toes he loketh vp and doun
Him deynes not to sette his fete to ground
And clokkith whan he hath a corne I founde
And to him than ran his wyues alle
Thus riall as a prince in his halle
Leue I this Chaunteclere in his pasture
And aftir will I telle his aduenture
Whan the month in which the world began
That hiȝt Marche that god first made man
Was complet and passed were also
Synnes Marche began xxxty daies and two
Bifell that Chaunteclere in all his pride
His vij wyues walkyng be his side
Cast vp his yen to the briȝt sonne Chaıı̄untecler ~
That in the signe of Taurus had I ronne
Twenty degrees and oon and somdel more
He knewe be kynde and be subtill lore
That his prime he kreew with blisfull steuene
The sonne he seide is clomben vpon heuene
Twenty degrees and oon and more I wis
Madame Pertelote my worldeles blisse
Herke these blisfull birdes hou thei singe
And se the fressh floures hou thei springe
Full is myn herte of reuel and of solace
But sodeinly him fel a sorwefull case
For euer // ende the // latter of ioye is woo
God wot that wordly ioye is sone a goo
And if a retorik that can faire endite
In a cronicle saufly miȝt it write
As for a souerain notabilite
Now eueri wise man now let him herkene me
This story is also trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelet de lake
That wommen helde in full gret reuerence
Now wol I torne agein to my sentence
A Colefox full of sleithe and iniquite
That in the groue had woned yeres three
By his Imaginacioıı̄un aforn cast
The same niȝt throuȝ the hegge brast
In to the yerd ther Chaunteclere the faire
Was wonte and eke his wyues to repaire
And in bedde of wortes stille he lay
Till it was passed vndren of the day
Waiting his tyme on Chaunteclere to falle
As gladly doon theȝ homicides alle
That in awaite liggeth to murdre men
O false murderer lorkyng in thi den
O now scariot oo now genylounye Chauntecler ~
False dissimuloᵘur o gret Symonie
That brouȝtest Troye all outerly to sorwe
O Chaunteclere o cursed be that morwe
That thou in to the yerd fly fro the bemes
Thou were full warned by thi dremes
That thilke day was perlous to the
But that god woll mot nedes be
Aftir the opinioıı̄un of certain clerkes
Witnesse on him that any good clerk is
That in scole is gret altercacioıı̄un
In this case and gret disputacioıı̄un
And hath ben of an C . Mˢ . men
But I ne can bulte it to the bren
As can the holi doctour Augustyn
Or boecy or the busshop Bradwyn
Whethir that god for witing
Streyneth me nedely to do a thing
Nedeli clepe I necessite
Or if the free choise be graunted me
To do that same thing or to do it nouȝt
For god wot it or I was wrouȝt
Or of this weting streineth neuer a dele
But by necessite condicionell
I will not haue to do of such matere
My tale is of a Cok as ye may here
That toke his counseill of his wif with sorwe
To walke in the yerde vpon a morwe
That he had met the dreme that I you tolde
Wommans counsaill ben full ofte colde
Wommans counsaill brouȝt us first to woo
And made Adam from Paradis to go
Ther as he was full mery and wel at ese
But for I wol nat wommen in no thing displese
Yef I counceill of hem wolde blame Chaıı̄untecler ~
Passe ouer for I seid it in my game
Rede auctors where thei trete of such matere
And what thei sey of wommen here
These ben the bokes wordes and not myn
I can non harme of no womman deuyne
Faire in the sond to bathe her merily
Lyth Pertelote and all here susteris by
Ayen the sonne Chaunteclere so free
Songe merier than the mere maiden in the see
For phisiliogus saith witterly
Hou that thei singen wel and merily
And so befell o hou that he cast his ye
Among the wortes vpon a botterflie
He was ware of the fox that lay full lowe
No thing lust him than for to crowe
And cried oon Cok . Cok and vp he sterte
As a man that affraied were in his herte
For naturelly a beest desireth to flee
From his contrary if he may it see
Thouȝ he neuer est had seyn it with his ye
This Chauntecler whan he gan him spie
He wold a fled but the fox anon
Seide gentill sir allas whither will ye goon
Be ye affraied of me that am your frende
Now certes I were worse than a fende
If I to you wolde harme or vilanye
I am not comen your counseill to aspie
But truly the cause of my comyng
Was for to herken hou that ye syng
For truly ye haue as mery a steuene
As any aungell hath that is in heuene
Ther with ye haue in musik more feling
Than had Boys or any othir that can singe
My lord your fader god his soule blisse Chauntecler ~
And eke your moder of her gentilnesse
Han in my house I ben to me gret ese
And certes sir full fayn wol I you plese
But for men spekith of singing I will sey
So mote I wel brouken myn yen twey
Saue you I ne herde neuer man singe
As did your fader in the mornyng
Certes it was of hert all that he songe
And for to make his voice more strong
He wold so peynen him that with bothe his yen
He most winken so loude he wolde cryen
And stonde vpon his tiptoon ther with all
And strecchid forth his necke that was small
And eke he was of such discrecioıı̄un
That ther no was man in the regioıı̄un
That him in his song or wisdam miȝt passe
Yeu woll radde in daun thare asse
Among his verse ther was a Cok
For a prestis sone yaf him a cnok
Vpon his legges whiles he was yong and nise
He made him for to lese his benefice
But certein there is non comparisoıı̄un
Bytwix the wisdam and discressioıı̄un
Of your fader and of his subtilitee
Now singeth sir for seint Charite
Late se conne ye your fadir counterfete
This Chauntecler his wenges gan bete
As man that coude nat this treson nat aspie
So was he rauisshed with his flaterie
¶ Allas ye lordes many a false flatour
Is in your court and many a losengoure
To plesen you more by my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse to you saith
Redeth Ecclesiastre of flaterie Chauntecler ~
Be war ye lordes of here treccherie
This Chauntecler stode hiȝe vpon his toes
Strecching his necke and hielde his yen close
And gan to crowe loude for the nones
And Daun Russell stert vp at ones
And by the gargate he hent Chauntecler
And on his bak toward the wode him bere
For yet was ther no man that it him shewid
O desteny maist thou nat be eschewid
Allas that Chaunteclere fill from the bemes
Allas his wif ne thouȝt on dremes
And on a friday fill all this mischaᵘnce
O venus that art goddesse of plesaunce
Sethenes that thi seruaunt was Chaunteclere
And in thi seruice did all his power
More for delite than the world to multiplie
Whi woldest thou suffre him on thi day to dye
O gaufred dere maistir souerain
That whan thi worthi king Richard was slayn
Whi ne haddest thou compleyned his deth so sore
Whi ne had I now thi sentence and thi lore
The friday for to chiden as dide ye
For on a friday sothely slayn was he
Than woll I shewe you hou that I coude pleyne
For Chauntecleres loue and for his peyne
Certes such crye ne lamentacioıı̄un
As the ladyes whan ylioıı̄un
And whan Pirous with his streite swerde
Hent kyng Pryom by the berd
And slowe him as seith Enides
Made neuer as the hennes in the close
Whan thei had sey of Chaunteclere this siȝt
But souereinly Dame Pertelote shriȝt
Well louder than did Hastrubaldes wif Chauntecler ~
Whan that her husbond had lost his lif
And that romayns had brent cartage
She was so full of torment and of rage
That welfully in to the fire she stert
And brent her self with a stedfast hert
O wofull hennes riȝt so criden ye
As whan that Nero brend the Citee
Of Rome crieden the senatours wyues
For that her husbondes losten her lyues
Withouten gilt this Nero hath hem slayn
Now woll I torne to my tale a gein
This seli widewe and her douȝteres two
Herden these hennes crieden and maden woo
And out at the dore stert thei anon
And sawe the fox toward the wode goon
And bare vpon his bak the Cok awey
And cried out harrow and welawey
A . ha the fox and aftir him thei ran
And eke with staues many an othir man
Ran . Collow oure dogge Talbot and Gerland
And Malkyn with a distaf in her hand
Ran cow and calf and eke the veri dogges
So ferd were for berking of the dogges
And shoutyng of the men and the wommen eke
Thei ronne so hem thouȝte here herte breke
Thei yellid as fendes doon in helle
The dogges cried as men wolde hem quelle
The gees for fere flowen ouer the trees
Out of the hyues came the swarm of bees
So hidous was the noise a Benedicite
Certes Iak straw and his mene
Ne made neuer shoutes half so shrille
Whan that they wolden any fleming kille
As thilk day was made vpon the fox Pertelot ~
Of bras thei brouȝten bemes and of box
Of horne and bone in which thei blew and pouped
And ther with all thei steked and thei houped
It semed as that heuene shuld falle
Now gode men herkenith alle
Loo hou fortune torneth sodeinly
The hope and pride eke of her enmy
This Cok that lay vpon this foxes bak
In all his drede vnto the fox he spak
And seid sir as if that I were as ye
Yet shuld I sey as wistly god helpe me
Turneth ayen ye proude cherles alle
A verry pestilence vpon you falle
Now am I come to the wodes side
Maugre your hede the Cok shall here abide
The fox answerid in feith it shall be doon
I will him ete in feith and that anon
And he spak that word all sodeinly
This Cok brak from his mouth delyuerly
And whan the fox saw that he was goon
And hiȝe vpon a tree he fly anoon
Allas qd he . A chaunteclere allas
I haue to you don qd he a trespas
In as moche as I haue maked you a ferd
Whan I you hent and brouȝt you to this yerd
But sir I did it to no wickid entent
Come a doun and I shall telle you what I ment
I shall sey soth to you god helpe me so
Nay than qd he than I shrewe us bothe ij
And first I shrewe my self bothe blood ⁊and bones
Yf thou begile me any ofter than ones
Thou shalt nomore with thi flatery
Do me to singe and winke with myn ye
For he that winketh whan that he shulde see Phisicus ~
All welfully / god let him neuer the
Nay qd the fox god yef him meschaᵘnce
That is so indiscret of gouernᵃnce
That iangeleth whan he shuld holde his pees
Loo such it is to be reccheles
And necligent and trust on flaterie
But ye that holden this tale a folie
As of a fox and of a Cok and of an henne
Takith the moralitee gode men
For seint Poule seith all that writen is
To oure doctrine it is writen I wis
Taketh the frute and let the chaf be stille
Now gode god if it be thi wille
As seith my lord so make us alle gode men
And bringe us to his hiȝe blisse Amen .

l.hi:
Here endith the Nonnes Prestes tale .
And here beginneth A tale of the Maister of Phisik

div.l: (base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
(base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
(base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
(base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
(base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
(base) Which afterward may greve þeim sore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
(base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
(base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede
(base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
(base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
(base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
