div.l: Ther was a kniȝt that loued and did his payne
And many a labour and many a gret emprise
To serue a lady in his best wise
He for his lady wrouȝt or she was wonne
For she was on the fairest vnder the sonne
And eke therto come of so hiȝe kynrede
That wel vnnethe dorst this kniȝt for drede
Telle her his woo and his distresse
But at the last she for his worthinesse
And namely for his meke obeissaunce
Hath such pitee cauȝt for his penᵃnce Arueragus .
That priuely she fel of his accord
To take him for her husbond and her a lord
Of such lordship as men han ouer her wyues
And for to lede the more in blisse her lyues
Of his free will swor he as a kniȝt
That neuer in all his lif be day ne niȝt
Ne shulde vpon him take no maistrie
Ageins her will ne kithe her ielousye
But to her obeie and folwe her will in all
As any louer to his lady shall
Saue that the name of souereynte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
She thankid him and with gret humblesse
She seide sir sith of your gentilnesse
Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
Ne wold neuer god bitwix us tweyne
As in my gilt were eithir woo or strif
Sir I will be your humble trewe wif
Haue here my trouthe till that myn herte breste
Thus beth thei bothe in quiete and in reste
But oo thing sires safly dar I sey
That frendes eueri to othir must obeie
If thei will longe holde company
Loue will nat be constreyned be maistry
Whan mastrie cometh the god of loue anon
Beteth the wynges and farwel he is goon
Loue is a thing as any spirit free
Wommen of kynde desiren liberte
And nat to be constreyned as a thrall
And so don men if the soth seyn shall
Loke that who most pacienty is in loue
He is at his auauntage al a boue
Pacience is an hiȝe vertu certeyn
For it venquesseth as this clerkes seyn Dorigen .
Thinges that rigour shulde neuer atteyne
And of ech aduersite no wisdam is to compleyne
Lerneth to suffre orellis so mote I goon
Ye shull it lerne whedir ye will or noon
For in this world certein there no wiȝt is
That he ne doth or seith somtyme amys
Ire sekenesse or constellacioıı̄un
Wyn woo or chᵃunging of complexiou
Causeth full ofte to do amys or speken
On eueri wrong a man may not be wreken
Aftir the tyme most be temꝑper/paraunce
To eueri wiȝt that can discret gouernᵃunce
And therfor hath this worthi wise kniȝt
To lyue in ese sufferaunce he be hiȝt
And she to him ful wisely began to swere
That neuer shulde ther be defaute in here
Here may men see in humble wise accord
Thus hath she take her husbond and here lord
Seruᵃnt in loue and lord in mariage
Then was he bothe in lordship and seruage
Seruage nay but in lordship a boue
Sith he hath bothe his lady and his loue
His lady certes and his wif also
The which that lawe of loue accordeth to
And whan he was in his prosperite
Home with his wif he goth to his contre
Nat fer fro Pepinark there his dwelling was
Where as he liueth in blisse and in solas .
¶ Who coude telle but if he had weddid be
The ioye the ese and the prosperite
That is betwix an husbond and a wif
A yere and more lastid this blisful lif
Till that this kniȝt of which I speke of thus
That of Caired was cleped Arueragus Arueragus .
Shope him to go and dwelle a yere or tweyne
In Engelond that clepid was Britayne
To seke in armes worship and honoᵘur
For alle his lust he sette in such labour
And dwellid there ij yere the boke seith thus
Now will I stynte of this Arueragus
And speke I wol of Dorigen his wif
That loueth her husbond as her hertes lif
For his absence wepith she and siketh
As don these noble wyues whan hem liketh
She morneth waketh waileth fasteth pleyneth
Desire of his presence her so distreyneth
That all this wilde worlde she set at nouȝt
Here frendes which that knewe her heuy thouȝt
Conforten here in all that euer they may
Thei prechen her thei tellen her niȝt and day
That causeles she sleeth her self allas
And eueri comfort possible in this case
Thei done to her all her besinesse
Al for to make her lete her heuinesse
By processe as ye knowen euerichoıı̄un
Men may so longe graue in a ston
Till som figure there yn emprentid be
So longe han thei conforted her til she
Receyued hath by hope and by resoıı̄un
The emprentyng of here consolacioıı̄un
Throuȝ which her gret sorwe gan aswage
She may not alwey dure in such rage
And eke Arueragus in all her care
Hath sent her letteres home of all his welfare
And that he wil come hasteli ayen
Orellis had this sorwe her herte slayn
Her frendes saw her sorwe gan to slake
And praied her on knees for goddes sake Dorigen .
To come and romen her in companye
Awey to dryue her derke fantasy
And finally she graunted that request
For wel she say that it was for the beste

Sith that so many han hem selue slayn Dorigen .
Wel rather than they wolde defouled be
I wolde conclude that it is best for me
To sleen my self than defouled be thus
I wol be trewe to Arueragus
Or rather sleen my self in som manere
As did Demociones douȝter dere
Be cause that she wold nat defouled be
Of Cedasus it is full gret pitee
To rede hou thi douȝteren dide Allas
That slowe her seluen for such a maner caas
A gret pitee was it or wel more
The Thebane mayde that for Miȝtamore
Her self slow riȝt for such maner woo
An othir Theban mayde did riȝt soo
For oon of Macedonye had her oppressid
She with her deth her maydenhed redressid
What shall I say of Nyterates wif
That for such a caas beraft hir self hir lif
Hou two eke was to Altebrades
His loue that for to dyen ches
Than for to suffre his body vnburied be
Loo which a wif Alcestan was qd she
What seith Emer of gode Penelope
All grece knoweth of her chastite
Parde of lodomya is writen thus
That whan at Troye was slayn Prothesalanus
No lenger wolde she lyue after his day
The same of noble Porcia telle I may
Withoute Britons coude she not lyue
To whom she had her herte all hole yeue
The parfiȝt wifhod of Arthemasye
Honoured is throuȝ out all the barbary
O teuta quene thi wifly chastite
To alle wyues may a mirrour be Arueragus .
Thus playned Dorigen a day or tweyne
Purposing euer that she wolde deyen
But natheles vpon the thridde niȝt
Home come Arueragus this worthi kniȝt
And axed here whi that she wepe so sore
And she gan wepe euir the lenger the more
Allas qd she that euer I was born
Thus haue I seid qd she thus haue I sworn
And hath him told all as ye haue herd before
It nedeth nat reherce you nomore
This husbond with a glad chiere in a frendely wise
Answerid and seid as I shal you deuyse
Is there ouȝt ellis Dorigen but this
Nay nay qd she god helpe me so I wys
This is to moch and it were goddis wille
Ye wif qd he let slepe that is stille
It may be paraduenture yet to day
Ye shul your trouth holde be my fay
For god so wisly haue mercy on me
I had ful leuer I stiked deed for to be
For verri loue which that I to you haue
But if ye shuld your trouthe kepe and saue
Trouthe is the hiȝest thing that men may kepe
But with that word he brast anon to wepe
And seid I you forbede vpon peyne of deth
That neuer whil the lasteth lif or breth
To no wiȝt telle of this aduenture
As I may best I will my woo endure
Ne make no contenᵃnce of heuynesse
That folk of you may deme or gesse
And forth she clepith a squier and a maide
Goo forth anon with Dorigen he saide
And bringeth her to such a place anoon
They take her and on her wey thei goon Aurelius .
But ne wist why she thider wente they
He nolde no wiȝt tellen his entent
This squier which that hight Aurelius
On Dorigen which that was so amerous
Of Aduenture happid her to mete
Amidde the toun in the quikkest strete
As she was boun the wey to goo forth riȝt
Toward the gardyn ther as she had hiȝt
And he was to the gardyn ward also
For wel he spied whan she shuld goo
Out of her house to eny maner place
But thus thei mette of auenture or grace
And he salueth her with glad entent
And axed her whiderward she went
And she answerid half as she were mad
Vnto the gardyn as my husbond bad
My trouthe for to holde Allas Allas
Aurelius gan wonder on this caas
And in his herte had gret compassioıı̄un
Of her and of her gret lamēmtacioıı̄un
And of Arueragus the worthi kniȝt
That bad her holde all that she hiȝt
So loth he was his wif shuld breke her trouth
And in his herte of this he cauȝt gret routh
Considering the best in eueri side
That from his lust yet had him leuer a bide
Than don so hiȝt a cherles wrecchidnesse
Ageins Fraunchise and all gentilnesse
For which in fewe wordes seide he thus
Madame seith to your lord Arueragus
That sith I see his gret gentillesse
To you and eke I see your distresse
That him were leuer haue shame and that were routhe
Than ye to me thus shuld breke your trouthe Dorigen .
I haue wel leuer euer to suffre woo
Than I departe the loue betwix you two
I you relese madame in to your honde
Quyte euer surement and euir bonde
That ye han made to me as here beforn
Sethin thilke tyme which ye were born
My trouth I pliȝt I shall neuer you repreue
Of no beheste and here I take my leue
As for the trewest and the best wif
That euer yet I knewe in all my lif
She thanked him vpon her knees al bare
And hom vnto her husbond is she fare
And tolde him all as ye haue herd me seid
And be ye siker he was so wel apaied
That it were nat possible for me to write
That shuld lenger of this case endite
But eueri wif bewar of her behest
On Dorigen remembreth at the leste
Thus can a squier don a gentil dede
As wel as can a kniȝt withouten drede
¶ Arueragus and Dorigen his wif
In souerein blisse leden forth her lif
Neueʳ aftir was ther angre hem bitwene
He cherissheth her as thouȝ she were a quene
And she was to him trewe for euermore
Of these ij folk ye gete of me namore
Aurelius that his coste hath all for lorn
Cursith the tyme that euer he was born
Allas qd he Allas that I behiȝt
Of pured gold A Mˢ. pound of wiȝt
Vnto this Philisophre hou shal I doo
I see nomore that but I am vndoo
Myn heritage mote I nedes selle
And be A Begger here may not dwelle Arueragus .
And shamen all my kynred in this place
But I of him may gete better grace
But natheles I will of him assaie
At certain daies by yere to paye
And thonke him of his gret curtesie
My trouth I wil kepe I wil nat lye
With herte sore he goth vnto his cofre
And brouȝt gold vnto this philosophre
The valu of . v . līm as I gesse
And him beseketh of his gentilesse
To graunt him daies of the remenᵃnt
And seide Maistir I dar make avaunt
I failed neuer of my trouth as yet
For sikerly my dette shall be quyt
Towardes you hou that euer I fare
To gon a begged in my doublet bare
But wolde ye vouchesaf vpon surete
Two yere or thre to respiten me
Than were I wel orellis mot I selle
Myn heritage ther is no more to telle
This Philosophre priuely answerid
And seid thus whan he ther wurdes herde
Haue I not helde couenᵃnt vnto the
Yes certes well and truly qd he
Hast thou nat had thi lady as the liketh
No qd he and sorwefully he siketh
What was the cause telle me if thou can
Aurelius his tale anon began
And tolde him all as ye haue herd before
It nedeth nat toto you reherce it more
And seid Arueragus of gentilnesse
Had leuer dye in sorwe and in distresse
Than that his wif were of her trouthe fals
The sorwe of Dorigen he tolde als Dorigen .
How loth her was to be a wicked wif
And that she leuer had that day lost her lif
And that her throuthe she swore throuȝ ynnocence
She neuer erst had herde speke of apparence
That made me had of her so gret pitee
That riȝt as frely as he sent here to me
As frely sent I her to him agein
This is all and som ther is namore to seyn
This Philosophre answerid leue brothir
Euerich of you dede gentely to othir
Thou art a squier and he is a kniȝt
But god forbede for his blisful miȝt
But if A Clerc coude don a gentil dede
As wel as any of you it is no drede
Sir I relese the thi thousand pound
As thou riȝt now were cropen out of the grounde
Ne neuer or now haddist knowe me
For sir I wil nat take A peny of the
For all my craft ne nouȝt for my trauaile
Thou hast I paied wel for my vitaile
It is I nouȝ and fare wel and haue gode day
And toke his hors and forth he goth his way
Lordinges this questioıı̄un will I axe now
Which was the most fre as thinketh you
Now telleth me or that ye further wende
I can nomore my tale is an ende.
Here endeth the tale of the Marchaunt .

Here endeth the tale of the Marchaunt .
And here beginneth the Prolog of the Persoıı̄un .

l.hi: han the Marchᵃnt had his tale endid

div.l: The sonne fro the south side is discendid
So lowe that he was not to my siȝt
Degrees . xxix as of hiȝt P
Ten of the clokke it was as I gesse
For enleuene foot a litil more or lesse
My shadewe was thilke tyme as there
As such feete as my lengthe partid were
In sixe feet equall of proporcioun
Ther with the mones exaltacioıı̄un
I mene libra alwey gan ascende
As we were entryng at the thropes ende
For with oure oost as he was wont to gye
And in this caas oure ioly companye
Saide in this wise lordinges euerichoıı̄un
Now lakketh us no tale more than oon
All most fulfilled is myn ordenᵃnce
I pray to god so yef him riȝt gode chᵃunce
That tellith this tale to vs lustily
Sir preest qd he art thou A vikery
Or art thou a person sey soth be thi fay
Be what thou be breke nat oure play
For eueri man saf thou hath told his tale
Vnbokele and shewe us what is in thi male
For truly me thinketh be thi chiere
Thou shuldest knytte vp wel a gret matere
A telle us A fable anon for cokkes bones
This persoıı̄un than answerid al at ones
Thou getest fable non tolde for me
For Poule that writeth vnto the Thimothe
Repreueth hem that wayueth sothfastnesse
And tellen fables and such wrecchidnesse
Whi shuld I shewe draf out of my fist
Whan I may shewe wete if that me list
For which I say if that thou list to here
Moralite and vertuous matere
And than that ye wil yeue me audience
I will ful fayn at Cristes reuerence R
Do you plesaunce liefue as I can
Trusteth wel I am A Sutheroıı̄un man
I can no geste rum . rum . ruf by letter
Ne gode wot ryme hold I litill bettir
And therfor if thou like I wil nat glose
I will you telle a mery tale in prose
To knitte vp all this feste and make an ende
And Ihıı̄un for his grace wit me sende
To shewe you the way in this viage
Of thilke parfiȝt glorious pilgrimage
That hiȝt Iherusalem celestiall
And if ye vouchesaf anon I shall
Begynne vpon my tale wherfor I pray
Telle your aduise I can no better say
But natheles this meditacioıı̄un
I put it ay vnder correttioıı̄un
Of clerkes for I am not textuel
I take but the sentence trusteth well
And therfor I make protestacioıı̄un
That I will stonde to correccioıı̄un
Vpon this worde we han assented sone
For as it semed it was to done
To ende in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue him space and audience
And bad oure oost he shuld to him seye
That alle we to telle his tale him preye
Oure oost had the wordes for us alle
Sir prest qd he now faire mote the befalle
Say what ye list and we shall gladly here
And with that word he seid in this manere
Tellith qd he your meditacioıı̄un
But hasteth you the sonne wil a doun
Beth fructuous and that in litil space
And to do wel god send you his grace .
